children.subject: I  kinda liked the circuit parts (although I'm not that big of a fan on the lab) and we're currently on module 2 which has been kinda interesting as well
<md>If you like module 2 and a bit of module 1 then I recommend EE 128</md>
thank you! are there any areas/classes in ee fields that also use programming or are they generally separate? thanks!

Almost all of EE uses programming. You would have to look pretty hard to avoid it. Analog circuit analysis is done with SPICE decks (scripts that describe a circuit layout). Even people in device physics and power electronics use scripting languages like Python and Matlab to automate data acquisition.

However, I suspect you might be asking this question in the context of programming like you've done in 61AB, where the programs themselves are the interesting part of the work.

For low-level programming, computer architecture (where EE and CS cross) and is very heavy in Assembly and Verilog. This kind of coding might not be your cup of tea though (61C is the most relevant lower div).

Otherwise for high-level programming, you want to look at signal processing. Signal processing is focused on applying math to real-world data analysis problems. As a result, this definitely involves a lot of coding and is similar in spirit to the 170 projects, but the algorithms you write have to be hardware-optimized in addition to being computationally efficient.

Signal processing engineers value not only writing a program that is algorithmically efficient but optimizing down to the instruction level since SP hardware tends to be low-power stuff that doesn't have a lot of compute.

thank you so much for your reply! If I were interested in signal processing should I prioritize taking EE126 or EE127 (a lot of other classes aren't offered next fall)? Should I also try to get involved in research on campus? thank you so much this was really helpful!

As Atom stated above, you cannot avoid programming in EE -- it goes hand in hand. A lot of the times EE uses a lot of low level languages like C++/C for designing embedded systems and usually a high level language like Python to test/script the devices.

For EE generally, take EE120 first. It is an IMPORTANT foundational class for any EE class at Berkeley or in general. Take it in Spring 2022 when Babak teaches it. Best teacher I've ever had in Cal and you'll learn so much. 

If you like the circuits part of Module 1 -- Take 105 -> 140.  You don't need EE120 to do 105/140 so you can slot this in whenever in your schedule. I think 105 has you to design an op-amp from transistors and 140's final project is designing a cadence amplier from scratch. 140 is enough for you to get a job in analog design anywhere. Apple sponsors 140 and recruits students from the class directly too. 

If you like Module 2 (controls) -- Take 128 and 106A-106B series. 128 is a feedback control class where you learn different techniques of frequency based design and some pretty cool controls in general. Kinda theoritical but the final project when I took it had you code up a controller on a drone to track differnt things. 106A-B is a robotics based class where you learn imaging, controls, kinematics, etc. 106A is mostly linear algebra and theory (pretty low workload and straightforward) where 106B focuses more on research and implementing hard theories learnt in class and from 106A. 106B is significantly more rewarding but is also significantly harder and time consuming (am currently dying in 106B). 

If you like Module 3 -- Take 127/189

For signal processing, 127/126 is pretty useless as you would wanna take 123 where 120 is a prereq that isn't enforced but I don't see how you can do it without 120 (I'm in the class rn). Maybe 126 can be somewhat useful since noise is present in signal processing daily and learning to deal with that is a nice touch but 126 is an overkill. 123 is a great class and the labs are awesome. You can actually do some sick signal processing with a cheap hardware 123 gives you to decode airplane locations and signals. 

For digital design, look into 61C -> 151. 151 is regarded as THE class to take if you wanna do hardware engineer. Literally just by having this class in your resume, every hardware company wants to interview you instantly. The class is a 5 unit class where you learn Verilog and a lot of low-level design. Apple also sponsors this class by giving out free airpods for the best designs in the final project and recruits students from this class (myself and my friends in Fa20). Caution, its a really hard class since the learning curve is steep. 

I think outside of the EE classes, I think it would be generally useful to take CS162 to supplement the EE route. A lot of EE is system designs and 162 is pretty useful for you to learn and implement an entire operating system. Throw in CS170 too if you have time cause optimizing algorithms is also a big part of EE.

For signal processing, you NEED to have 151. 

Signal processing with general-purpose x86 hardware has basically evolved into machine learning, so most SP work nowadays involves real-time data processing. FPGAs are designable circuit architectures that can be programmed to run SP algos at the hardware level, which makes it easier to interface with I/O and achieve low latency, two things that are absolutely essential.

I saw that 61c isn't offered as a prereq for 151. would it make sense to take 61c with 151 next sem? I'm still trying to figure out my schedule since some of the classes I wanna take aren't offered next sem. I was currently thinking about cs61c, math 53 (is this needed for upper div ee classes?), and a cs class, but I'm still deciding if I should swap anything with ee126/127. thank you all so much, the advice has been really helpful!!

Math 53 is actually really important for EE 117 (and to a lesser extent 118), but for the rest of the EE upper divs, it shouldn't be too much of a problem. The most you'll need is a partial derivative or an easy surface integral.

Don't do 151 without 61C. Even though it's not an enforced prereq, it really should be. Everything in 151 builds on 61C.

Your last class on top of 61C and 53 could be either 105 or 120, both of which only need 16B. These two classes also highlight the two major "themes" of EE, devices/circuits and control/signal processing so you should aim to take both as soon as possible to see which side is a better fit for you.

I see unfortunately I don't think any of them are offered next sem :(( https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Scheduling/EE/schedule-draft.html

I think the only courses that might be kinda relevant that I can take are 126/127

I would wait for the official schedule to come out as who knows how it may compare to the draft. I would say to not wait and **take EE 120 ASAP** no matter who is teaching since the course is sooo foundational, although Babak is universally loved. If you like theory and want to go into that side of anything EECS, it would be reallllly good to have 126/127, especially for signal processing/controls. Anything interesting at the grad level pretty much requires a good probability and optimization backbone.
What anon comp said is true. If you can't wait to take EE120 with Babak, heres the webcasted version when I took it in Sp2020: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkFD6_40KJIwfL-CQnMHVPI_QjlF8mW2O
thank you so much! will check out

history.content: I'm unsure which upper division courses I should take (currently have done CS 170 and Data 100). I like the coding projects we got to do in CS 61b and I like coding in general, and I also feel like the different applications we learned in EE 16b were really cool (but there wasn't that much coding and I feel alright about math). Does anyone have any recommendations for different fields I should take more classes in or do more research on? Thanks!
